item.title: By: Mark Holmes
item.dc:creator: Mark Holmes
item.content:encoded:
Yes, I read a number of stories several years ago where someone found a surprise $20,000+ cell phone bill after their kid went on a school trip – literally just across the Canadian border, thereby activating roaming. Their efforts to fight the bill were unsuccessful because, well, a contract is a contract.

AT&T charges an insane amount if you don’t opt-in to a monthly plan. It’s a horrible business model – the default action used to be that wireless carriers would charge the maximum, wait 30-45 days before informing the customer, and wham. Only after the national media caught on did they offer the alert text that you got. Imagine if you didn’t pay attention to that message – or if you had Google+ or Dropbox auto-upload enabled for your new photos.

International travelers really do need to pay attention to this until carriers offer a default “spending limit” to stop losses. I should be asked to confirm I really intend to spend more than, say, 200% of my normal bill.
